title: World War II bunker conversion: Yelta property for sale as a house
text:
A top-secret World War II bunker has hit the market as a house.

The quirky Yelta home began its life in 1941, as one of several structures built by the Royal Australian Air Force to store fuel for its nearby Mildura base, owner Stephen Gooding said.

He said with the Japanese a wartime threat, the 8mm-thick steel bunkers were encased in reinforced concrete, built into the side of a hill and covered with dirt.

“They were top secret back in those days — there was barbed wire everywhere,” Mr Gooding said.

“They closed them up in 1945, after the war, and then they were privatised. I bought four of them 30 years ago.”

He converted one into “a six-bedroom underground house” for himself and his wife Fran, has sold off another two, and now he and his son Zachary have listed the fourth.

That bunker, set on 5000sq m of land at 2 Nemstas Lane, has a $260,000-$280,000 price guide for its November 16 auction.

While it once held a million litres of aviation fuel, it now contains an open-plan living and dining space with a modern kitchen, four bedrooms and two bathrooms on its ground floor.

The top storey remains a shell, ready to be converted by the next owner.

Mr Gooding said the bunkers were “a constant 20C all year round”, ensuring low heating and cooling costs, and exceptionally private.

“You can’t hear your neighbours,” he said.

They had been visited by people who’d worked on the bunkers during the war, and had also dug into their history shortly after buying them.

“We went to archives to get the history and it was still an enclosed file, top secret from the war,” he said.

“We paid $75 or whatever it was to get it opened. No one had ever bothered to look into it.”

Professionals Mildura selling agent Tony Graham expected the Nemstas Lane pad to appeal to buyers seeking “peace and quiet”, or a “blank canvas”.

It priced for first-home buyers, but would also suit as a holiday getaway, being close to the Murray River.

Zachary had lived at the house with his wife, Bianca, and son, Charlie, with the family selling to move to Queensland.

description: Attention history buffs — here’s your chance to make a classified former air force bunker your very own digs. The regional Victorian home with a covert past has just landed on the market.
